tools.name: CountStargazers
tools.description:
Count the number of stargazers (stars) for a GitHub repository.
For example, to count the number of stars for microsoft/vscode, you would use:
```
count_stargazers(owner="microsoft", name="vscode")
```

parameters.name: owner
parameters.description: The owner of the repository

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the repository

output.description: The number of stargazers (stars) for the specified repository

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: CreateIssue
tools.description:
Create an issue in a GitHub repository.

Example:
```
create_issue(
    owner="octocat",
    repo="Hello-World",
    title="Found a bug",
    body="I'm having a problem with this.",
    assignees=["octocat"],
    milestone=1,
    labels=["bug"],
)
```

parameters.name: owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repo
parameters.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: title
parameters.description: The title of the issue.

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: The contents of the issue.

parameters.name: assignees
parameters.description: Logins for Users to assign to this issue.

parameters.name: milestone
parameters.description: The number of the milestone to associate this issue with.

parameters.name: labels
parameters.description: Labels to associate with this issue.

parameters.name: include_extra_data
parameters.description: If true, return all the data available about the pull requests. This is a large payload and may impact performance - use with caution.

output.description: A JSON string containing the created issue's details, including id, url, title, body, state, html_url, creation and update timestamps, user, assignees, and labels. If include_extra_data is True, returns all available data about the issue.

body.value: There's a major issue causing the application to crash.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: CreateIssueComment
tools.description:
Create a comment on an issue in a GitHub repository.

Example:
```
create_issue_comment(owner="octocat", repo="Hello-World", issue_number=1347, body="Me too")
```

parameters.name: owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repo
parameters.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: issue_number
parameters.description: The number that identifies the issue.

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: The contents of the comment.

parameters.name: include_extra_data
parameters.description: If true, return all the data available about the pull requests. This is a large payload and may impact performance - use with caution.

output.description: A JSON string containing the created comment's details, including id, url, body, user, and creation and update timestamps. If include_extra_data is True, returns all available data about the comment.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: CreateReplyForReviewComment
tools.description:
Create a reply to a review comment for a pull request.

Example:
```
create_reply_for_review_comment(
    owner="octocat",
    repo="Hello-World",
    pull_number=1347,
    comment_id=42,
    body="Looks good to me!",
)
```

parameters.name: owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repo
parameters.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: pull_number
parameters.description: The number that identifies the pull request.

parameters.name: comment_id
parameters.description: The unique identifier of the comment.

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: The text of the review comment.

output.description: JSON string containing details of the created reply comment

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: CreateReviewComment
tools.description:
Create a review comment for a pull request in a GitHub repository.

If the subject_type is not 'file', then the start_line and end_line parameters are required.
If the subject_type is 'file', then the start_line and end_line parameters are ignored.
If the commit_id is not provided, the latest commit SHA of the PR's base branch will be used.

Example:
```
create_review_comment(
    owner="octocat",
    repo="Hello-World",
    pull_number=1347,
    body="Great stuff!",
    commit_id="6dcb09b5b57875f334f61aebed695e2e4193db5e",
    path="file1.txt",
    line=2,
    side="RIGHT"
)
```

parameters.name: owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repo
parameters.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: pull_number
parameters.description: The number that identifies the pull request.

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: The text of the review comment.

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: The relative path to the file that necessitates a comment.

parameters.name: commit_id
parameters.description: The SHA of the commit needing a comment. If not provided, the latest commit SHA of the PR's base branch will be used.

parameters.name: start_line
parameters.description: The start line of the range of lines in the pull request diff that the comment applies to. Required unless 'subject_type' is 'file'.

parameters.name: end_line
parameters.description: The end line of the range of lines in the pull request diff that the comment applies to. Required unless 'subject_type' is 'file'.

parameters.name: side
parameters.description: The side of the diff that the pull request's changes appear on. Use LEFT for deletions that appear in red. Use RIGHT for additions that appear in green or unchanged lines that appear in white and are shown for context

parameters.name: start_side
parameters.description: The starting side of the diff that the comment applies to.

parameters.name: subject_type
parameters.description: The type of subject that the comment applies to. Can be one of: file, hunk, or line.

parameters.name: include_extra_data
parameters.description: If true, return all the data available about the review comment. This is a large payload and may impact performance - use with caution.

output.description: JSON string containing details of the created review comment

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: GetPullRequest
tools.description:
Get details of a pull request in a GitHub repository.

Example:
```
get_pull_request(owner="octocat", repo="Hello-World", pull_number=1347)
```

parameters.name: owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repo
parameters.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: pull_number
parameters.description: The number that identifies the pull request.

parameters.name: include_diff_content
parameters.description: If true, return the diff content of the pull request.

parameters.name: include_extra_data
parameters.description: If true, return all the data available about the pull requests. This is a large payload and may impact performance - use with caution.

output.description: JSON string containing details of the specified pull request, optionally including diff content

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: GetRepository
tools.description:
Get a repository.

Retrieves detailed information about a repository using the GitHub API.

Example:
```
get_repository(owner="octocat", repo="Hello-World")
```

parameters.name: owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repo
parameters.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: include_extra_data
parameters.description: If true, return all the data available about the repository. This is a large payload and may impact performance - use with caution.

output.description: A dictionary containing repository details such as name, full_name, html_url, description, clone_url, private status, creation/update/push timestamps, and star/watcher/fork counts

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: ListOrgRepositories
tools.description: List repositories for the specified organization.

parameters.name: org
parameters.description: The organization name. The name is not case sensitive

parameters.name: repo_type
parameters.description: The types of repositories you want returned.

parameters.name: sort
parameters.description: The property to sort the results by

parameters.name: sort_direction
parameters.description: The order to sort by

parameters.name: per_page
parameters.description: The number of results per page

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: The page number of the results to fetch

parameters.name: include_extra_data
parameters.description: If true, return all the data available about the repositories. This is a large payload and may impact performance - use with caution.

output.description: A dictionary with key 'repositories' containing a list of repositories, each with details such as name, full_name, html_url, description, clone_url, private status, creation/update/push timestamps, and star/watcher/fork counts

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: ListPullRequestCommits
tools.description:
List commits (from oldest to newest) on a pull request in a GitHub repository.

Example:
```
list_pull_request_commits(owner="octocat", repo="Hello-World", pull_number=1347)
```

parameters.name: owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repo
parameters.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: pull_number
parameters.description: The number that identifies the pull request.

parameters.name: per_page
parameters.description: The number of results per page (max 100).

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: The page number of the results to fetch.

parameters.name: include_extra_data
parameters.description: If true, return all the data available about the pull requests. This is a large payload and may impact performance - use with caution.

output.description: JSON string containing a list of commits for the specified pull request

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: ListPullRequests
tools.description:
List pull requests in a GitHub repository.

Example:
```
list_pull_requests(owner="octocat", repo="Hello-World", state=PRState.OPEN, sort=PRSort.UPDATED)
```

parameters.name: owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repo
parameters.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: state
parameters.description: The state of the pull requests to return.

parameters.name: head
parameters.description: Filter pulls by head user or head organization and branch name in the format of user:ref-name or organization:ref-name.

parameters.name: base
parameters.description: Filter pulls by base branch name.

parameters.name: sort
parameters.description: The property to sort the results by.

parameters.name: direction
parameters.description: The direction of the sort.

parameters.name: per_page
parameters.description: The number of results per page (max 100).

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: The page number of the results to fetch.

parameters.name: include_extra_data
parameters.description: If true, return all the data available about the pull requests. This is a large payload and may impact performance - use with caution.

output.description: JSON string containing a list of pull requests with their details

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: ListRepositoryActivities
tools.description:
List repository activities.

Retrieves a detailed history of changes to a repository, such as pushes, merges,
force pushes, and branch changes, and associates these changes with commits and users.

Example:
```
list_repository_activities(
    owner="octocat",
    repo="Hello-World",
    per_page=10,
    activity_type="force_push"
)
```

parameters.name: owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repo
parameters.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: direction
parameters.description: The direction to sort the results by.

parameters.name: per_page
parameters.description: The number of results per page (max 100).

parameters.name: before
parameters.description: A cursor (unique ID, e.g., a SHA of a commit) to search for results before this cursor.

parameters.name: after
parameters.description: A cursor (unique ID, e.g., a SHA of a commit) to search for results after this cursor.

parameters.name: ref
parameters.description: The Git reference for the activities you want to list. The ref for a branch can be formatted either as refs/heads/BRANCH_NAME or BRANCH_NAME, where BRANCH_NAME is the name of your branch.

parameters.name: actor
parameters.description: The GitHub username to filter by the actor who performed the activity.

parameters.name: time_period
parameters.description: The time period to filter by.

parameters.name: activity_type
parameters.description: The activity type to filter by.

parameters.name: include_extra_data
parameters.description: If true, return all the data available about the repository activities. This is a large payload and may impact performance - use with caution.

output.description: A JSON string containing a dictionary with key 'activities', which is a list of repository activities. Each activity includes id, node_id, before and after states, ref, timestamp, activity_type, and actor information

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: ListReviewCommentsInARepository
tools.description:
List review comments in a GitHub repository.

Example:
```
list_review_comments(owner="octocat", repo="Hello-World", sort="created", direction="asc")
```

parameters.name: owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repo
parameters.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: sort
parameters.description: Can be one of: created, updated.

parameters.name: direction
parameters.description: The direction to sort results. Ignored without sort parameter. Can be one of: asc, desc.

parameters.name: since
parameters.description: Only show results that were last updated after the given time. This is a timestamp in ISO 8601 format: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ.

parameters.name: per_page
parameters.description: The number of results per page (max 100).

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: The page number of the results to fetch.

parameters.name: include_extra_data
parameters.description: If true, return all the data available about the review comments. This is a large payload and may impact performance - use with caution.

output.description: A JSON string containing a dictionary with key 'review_comments', which is a list of review comments. Each comment includes id, url, diff_hunk, path, position details, commit information, user, body, timestamps, and related URLs

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

parameters.name: per_page

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: The page number of the results to fetch.

parameters.name: include_extra_data
parameters.description: If true, return all the data available about the review comments. This is a large payload and may impact performance - use with caution.

tools.name: SetStarred
tools.description:
Star or un-star a GitHub repository.
For example, to star microsoft/vscode, you would use:
```
set_starred(owner="microsoft", name="vscode", starred=True)
```

parameters.name: owner
parameters.description: The owner of the repository

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the repository

parameters.name: starred
parameters.description: Whether to star the repository or not

output.description: A message indicating whether the repository was successfully starred or unstarred

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: UpdatePullRequest
tools.description:
Update a pull request in a GitHub repository.

Example:
```
update_pull_request(
    owner="octocat",
    repo="Hello-World",
    pull_number=1347,
    title="new title",
    body="updated body",
)
```

parameters.name: owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repo
parameters.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: pull_number
parameters.description: The number that identifies the pull request.

parameters.name: title
parameters.description: The title of the pull request.

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: The contents of the pull request.

parameters.name: state
parameters.description: State of this Pull Request. Either open or closed.

parameters.name: base
parameters.description: The name of the branch you want your changes pulled into.

parameters.name: maintainer_can_modify
parameters.description: Indicates whether maintainers can modify the pull request.

output.description: JSON string containing updated information about the pull request

body.value: This updates the README with more examples.
